text: What is the type of information you want to collect from participants?
extra: Start by deciding what information you want to collect. Different types of output, such as text responses, labeled data, decisions, creative input, or feedback, determine both the task structure and the compensation model. Clearly defining the desired output helps align incentives with the task goals.

text: What do you hope this incentive will primarily help with?
extra: Define the outcome you want first. Clearly stating your objective upfront ensures the incentive structure actively guides participants toward the desired outcome rather than passively rewarding activity.
options: Meet minimum platform requirements for publishing
Increase participation
Encouraging greater effort and higher-quality work
Compensate fairly for greater effort and time-consuming task

text: Do you have a predefined budget?
extra: Determine upfront whether compensation is budget-constrained. When a fixed budget applies, state it explicitly early in the design process to prevent incentive models that are unrealistic or unsustainable at scale.
options: Yes, I have a fixed total budget
Yes, I have a rough estimate of total budget
No, I can be flexible with my budget

text: What is your total budget for this job?

answer: Yes, I have a fixed total budget
Yes, I have a rough estimate of total budget

text: Which strategy best fits your scenario?
extra: Every task must include a base payment. Start by evaluating how predictable the task's duration and effort are. Use this assessment to determine the appropriate payment strategy.
options: Fixed sum of money on completion time
Pay-rate that translates in varying income

text: How will you determine the amount you will award as fixed base pay?
extra: Fixed payments are easy to implement, but you must ensure they accurately reflect the effort required to complete the task.
options: Just use a flat amount of money
Estimate pay based on expected completion time

answer: Fixed sum of money on completion time

text: What is the amount of money you will be awarding?

answer: Just use a flat amount of money

text: How will you estimate how long it takes to complete the task?
extra: Estimating task duration helps ensure fair compensation.
options: Estimate completion time using heuristics based on similar tasks
Run a small pilot with real participants to measure completion time

answer: Estimate pay based on expected completion time

text: How many pilot studies do you plan to run?
extra: Plan multiple small pilot studies to capture variability in completion time. Use the results to refine compensation, especially when worker behavior is not uniform.

answer: Run a small pilot with real participants to measure completion time

text: With how many participants do you plan on testing?

answer: Run a small pilot with real participants to measure completion time

text: Which heuristics will you use to estimate task completion?
extra: Select explicit heuristics that translate effort into a concrete monetary amount. Avoid high-level guesswork and combine multiple heuristics to improve accuracy.

answer: Estimate completion time using heuristics based on similar tasks

text: What will you use as reference to determine the pay rate?
extra: Base the pay rate on a concrete external benchmark, not intuition.
options: Use the suggested amount provided by the crowdsourcing platform
Base the pay on hourly wages
Use heuristics to estimate a fair compensation

answer: Estimate completion time using heuristics based on similar tasks

text: Whose country's minimum wage will you use?
extra: Choose the country whose minimum wage you will use as a pay floor. Apply it consistently to establish a fair and transparent baseline across tasks.

answer: Base the pay on hourly wages

text: How will you use the minimum wage as reference point?

answer: Base the pay on hourly wages

text: What hourly pay-rate will you use?
extra: Choose an hourly rate by combining the external benchmark with an estimate of task effort, complexity, and quality requirements. Avoid flat or arbitrary rates that do not scale with expectations.

answer: Pay-rate that translates in varying income

text: Will you supplement the base pay with bonuses?
extra: Decide whether base pay alone sufficiently motivates the desired behavior. If not, introduce bonuses to influence effort, speed, or task completion.
options: Yes
No

text: On what will you be basing your bonus awarding?
extra: Select a concrete basis for awarding bonuses. Use it to directly align incentives with your intended outcome. Avoid vague or subjective criteria that do not clearly connect to the desired behavior.
options: On worker performance
On luck with rewards being given randomly
On completion, whether they finish the task or not

answer: Yes

text: Approximately how large will the bonus be?
extra: Determine the bonus amount based on the extra effort or uncertainty required beyond the base task. Ensure the bonus is substantial enough to motivate the desired behavior without being so large that it encourages gaming or overspending.

answer: On worker performance
On completion, whether they finish the task or not

text: What strategy will you use to implement luck-based bonuses?
extra: Decide whether bonuses will be awarded via a lottery, random draw, or probabilistic payout. Specify eligibility criteria, odds of winning, and payout amounts, and communicate these rules clearly to workers.

answer: On luck with rewards being given randomly

text: How will you measure worker performance?
extra: Identify specific, measurable criteria to assess worker performance.
options: Accuracy - how many correct answers have been given
Proprietary currency or score used in job
Manual review post-completion done by experts

answer: On worker performance

text: How will performance determine the bonus amount?
extra: Create an explicit, deterministic formula or mapping rule that converts performance metrics into bonus amounts. Apply it consistently across all workers to ensure fair compensation and reduce implementation complexity.
options: Fixed amount if a certain threshold is passed
Proportional to score if certain threshold is passed
Proportional to performance score
Use probabilistic scoring methods

answer: On worker performance

text: Do you think penalties are useful in your case?
extra: Introduce penalties only when there is a clear risk of cheating or low-quality behavior. Calibrate them carefully to avoid reducing participation.
options: Yes
No

answer: Yes

text: What sum will you substract as penalty?
extra: Limit penalties so they remain proportional to the task's base pay and bonuses. Penalties should deter unwanted behavior without becoming harmful.

answer: Yes

text: How will penalties be applied?

answer: Yes

text: How will you communicate your reward structure to workers?
extra: Communicate the complete reward structure clearly and upfront. Transparency around base pay, bonuses, and penalties is essential for trust and predictable worker behavior.
options: I will not tell them they will get something
I will tell them only when it happens (when bonus is given, when the pay is given etc)
I will tell them beforehand about the base pay, not the bonuses
I will tell them about everything
